decision_conditions: This consent shall be for a limited period only, expiring five years from the date of this consent. On or before that date the advertisement shall be removed and the building reinstated.Reason: This condition is specified by the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) Regulations 2007.

The luminance of the signs hereby granted consent shall not exceed 200 candela per square metre (cd/m2).Reason: In the interests of amenity, the free flow of traffic on the highway and road safety in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The illumination of the signs hereby granted consent shall be static and constant light; and shall contain no special effects of any kind (including noise, smell, smoke, animation, exposed cold cathode tubing, flashing, scrolling, three dimensional, intermittent or video elements).Reason: In the interest of highway safety and neighbouring amenity in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No advertisement to be displayed without the permission of the owner of the site or any other person with an interest in the site entitled to grant permission.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) regulations, 2007 in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No advertisement shall be sited or displayed so as to -(a) endanger persons using any highway, railway, waterway, dock, harbour or aerodrome (civil or military);(b) obscure, or hinder the ready interpretation of, any traffic sign, railway signal or aid to navigation by water or air; or(c) Hinder the operation of any device used for the purpose of security or surveillance or for measuring the speed of any vehicle.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) regulations, 2007 in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Any structure or hoarding erected or used principally for the purpose of displaying advertisements shall be maintained in a condition that does not endanger the public.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) regulations, 2007 in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Any advertisement displayed, and any site used for the display of advertisements, shall be maintained in a condition that does not impair the visual amenity.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) regulations, 2007 in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Where an advertisement is required under these Regulations to be removed, the site shall be left in a condition that does not endanger the public or impair visual amenity.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England).

DescriptionErection of a single storey rear extension to ground floor maisonette (No. 17) and new decking, fence and side gate.Consultations5no. surrounding properties were notified of the proposed development. No representations received.Planning HistoryNone.Site and SurroundingsThe application site is located on the north-eastern side of Vale Crescent and comprises of a 2-storey semi-detached dwelling which has been divided into 2no. flats. The planning application pertains to the ground floor flat, No. 17. The surrounding properties are of a similar design and appearance.The application site is not located within a Conservation Area and does not comprise of a statutory or locally listed building. Planning AssessmentThe key considerations in the assessment of this application are:-	Character and Appearance; and-	The Impact upon Residential AmenityCharacter and Appearance Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The proposed single-storey rear extension would not be visible from the street, contained to the rear. In relation to the existing building, the proposed extension is considered to be of an appropriate bulk and scale extending to be flush with the rear most elevation of the building so as to read as a subservient extension to the property. The matching brick walls to the rear extension are considered acceptable, in keeping with the rear elevation of the host building. Fencing and gate is proposed to match that which currently exists to No. 13 adjacent.Impact upon Residential AmenityPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 requires new development to deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity. Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) is clear that development proposals should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The upper level flat (No. 19) is not considered to be materially impacted by the proposals. No. 13 Vale Crescent is the adjoining ground floor flat to the south-east of the application property. The proposed extension would essentially infill an existing recessed element of the rear elevation of No.17 which would be sited immediately abutting the recessed element of No. 13. The proposed rear extension would measure to a depth of 4.5m along the boundary with this neighbour to a height of 3.3m.It is noted that a separate planning application has been submitted for No. 13 for the same proposals as those under consideration in this application to No. 17 (that is, under application reference: 21/02694/FUL). As such, the neighbouring extension of identical proportions is considered to adequately mitigate the potential harm which would otherwise be caused to the adjoining neighbour.A condition would be applied to ensure that the rear extension under app ref: 21/02694/FUL is built out simultaneously as that approved here, in order to ensure that there would indeed be no loss of residential amenity to the current/future residents of No. 13 Vale Crescent. As such, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of residential amenity.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the relevant policies of the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Core Strategy (2012).In conclusion, the proposal by virtue of its scale, design and materiality is considered to be subservient to the host dwelling and would not result in harm to the character and appearance of the host dwelling or wider area. In addition, the proposals would not result in materially harmful impact to neighbouring amenity by way of overlooking, loss of light or sense of overbearing or enclosure, subject to compliance with the attached condition relating to the application proposals submitted for the neighbouring property at No. 13.Recommendation:That planning permission be GRANTED

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

DescriptionErection of single storey rear extension and alterations to ground floor fenestration on ground floor maisonette (Flat 13).Consultations15no. surrounding properties were notified of the proposed development. No representations received.Planning HistoryApplication reference: 12/14423/HOU - Erection of single storey rear extension. Refused on 6th August 2012.ProposalThe application seeks full planning permission for the erection of a single-storey rear extension and alterations to ground floor fenestration on ground floor maisonette.Site and SurroundingsThe application site is located on the north-eastern side of Vale Crescent and comprises of a 2-storey semi-detached dwelling which has been divided into 2no. flats. The planning application pertains to the ground floor flat, No. 13. The surrounding properties are of a similar design and appearance.The application site is not located within a Conservation Area and does not comprise of a statutory or locally listed building. Planning AssessmentThe key considerations in the assessment of this application are:-	Character and Appearance; and-	The Impact upon Residential AmenityCharacter and Appearance Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The proposed single-storey rear extension would not be visible from the street, contained to the rear. In relation to the existing building, the proposed extension is considered to be of an appropriate bulk and scale extending to be flush with the rear most elevation of the building so as to read as a subservient extension to the property. The matching brick walls to the rear extension are considered acceptable, in keeping with the rear elevation of the host building. The proposals also include the removal of the existing side door and attached glazing and replacement with one window. The scale and design of the proposed window would complement those two side-facing window which already exist to the ground floor, and is therefore considered acceptable. Impact upon Residential AmenityPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 requires new development to deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity. Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) is clear that development proposals should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The upper level flat (No. 15) is not considered to be materially impacted by the proposals. No. 17 Vale Crescent is the adjoining ground floor flat to the south-east of the application property. The proposed extension would essentially infill an existing recessed element of the rear elevation of No.13 which would be sited immediately abutting the recessed element of No. 17. The proposed rear extension would measure to a depth of 4.5m along the boundary with this neighbour to a height of 3.3m.Officers note that the planning history of the site includes an application for similar proposals for a rear extension which was refused on the grounds of impact upon neighbouring residential amenity, specifically the impact upon No. 17, the adjacent ground floor flat.It is noted that a separate planning application has been submitted for No. 17 for the same proposals as those under consideration in this application to No. 13 (under application reference: 21/02695/FUL). As such, the previous concerns regarding the result visually overbearing, oppressive effect of the proposed rear extension and impact on outlook would no longer apply if the proposals were approved and built out to the neighbouring property. A condition would be applied to ensure that the rear extension under app ref: 21/02695/FUL is built out simultaneously as that approved here, in order to ensure that there would indeed be no loss of residential amenity to the current/future residents of No. 17 Vale Crescent. As such, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of residential amenity.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the relevant policies of the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Core Strategy (2012).In conclusion, the proposal by virtue of its scale, design and materiality is considered to be subservient to the host dwelling and would not result in harm to the character and appearance of the host dwelling or wider area. In addition, the proposals would not result in materially harmful impact to neighbouring amenity by way of overlooking, loss of light or sense of overbearing or enclosure, subject to compliance with the attached condition relating to the application proposals submitted for the neighbouring property at No. 17.Recommendation:That planning permission be GRANTED

The site comprises a commercial unit within the southern part of the Barwell Business Park which is designated as a Strategic Industrial Location (SIL).11 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Officer Comment: The application site is located within the southern part of the Barwell Business Park which is designated as a Strategic Industrial Location (SIL). The proposal seeks to replace the existing roof following extensive fire damage to the adjoining unit, and would replace it at a increased height. While the units within Barwell Business Park are notably uniform in appearance, officers consider that the raised height of the unit in this case would not be clearly noticeable as the increased height would be marginal and the design of the proposed roof would be very similar to existing. Further, given that the roof would be replaced in materials to match existing officers consider the proposed development to be acceptable.AmenityPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality. Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: The nearest residential properties are located approximately 169 metres away, to the north and north-west of the application site and as such subject to compliance with the Demolition Plan, the proposal would have no adverse impact on the residential amenity of these neighbouring properties, in terms of light pollution, loss of outlook, sunlight/daylight, loss of privacy, or increase in noise and disturbanceIn conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The development approved by this planning permission will be liable to pay the Mayor of London's Community Infrastructure Levy (MCIL). Payment will be due once the owner/developer serves a development Commencement Notice on the Council, and a payment Demand Notice has been received by the owner.  Failure to submit a Commencement Notice will incur a surcharge of 20% of the chargeable amount or £2,500, whichever is the lower amount. When you have [delete as appropriate] received approval of all reserved matters / discharged all pre-commencement conditions the Council will issue a Liability Notice to the owner setting out the MCIL calculation.  Accompanying the Liability Notice will be a  blank Commencement Notice and if necessary a blank Assumption of Liability form, both of which need to be completed and returned to the Council prior to development commencing.  A failure to do so will incur a surcharge. Should you have any questions in respect of the contents of this letter or the MCIL more generally, please contact the Council's Contact Centre by email mcil@rbk.kingston.gov.uk <mailto:mcil@rbk.kingston.gov.uk> or phone 0208 547 5002

The red outline in the submitted location plan is only in flat, please revise the red outline to show the proposed site including building, garden and compound.Please submit a copy of an Ordnance Survey based site location plan scaled 1:1250 with the application site outlined in red and adjoining land owned by applicant in blue, showing at least two road frontages and a North point.

The site address in the submitted application form is 46 Bolton Road, whereas the red outline in the location plan is 48 Bolton road, please revise the location plan with the correct site address.Please submit a copy of an Ordnance Survey based site location plan scaled 1:1250 with the application site outlined in red and adjoining land owned by applicant in blue, showing at least two road frontages and a North point.

Please provide a copy of proposed block plan scaled 1:500 showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site.  The block plan should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.The site address in the submitted application form is 46 Bolton Road, whereas the block plan is 48 Bolton road, please revise the block plan with the correct site address.
